verses.text: One of the wives of the sons of the prophets cried out to Elisha, saying, 'Your servant my husband is dead, and you know that your servant feared the LORD. Now the creditor has come to take my two children to be his slaves.'
verses.comment: Shows the context of debt slavery per Mosaic Law.

verses.text: Elisha said to her, 'What shall I do for you? Tell me, what do you have in the house?' She answered, 'Your servant has nothing in the house except a jar of oil.'
verses.comment: Oil was a valuable commodity, used for cooking and anointing.

verses.text: Then he said, 'Go around and ask all your neighbors for empty jars. Do not get just a few.'
verses.comment: Emphasizes collecting many jars for God’s miraculous provision.

verses.text: 'Then go in and shut the door behind you and your sons, and pour the oil into all these jars, setting aside each one when it is full.'
verses.comment: Closed doors show privacy for the miracle, similar to Matt. 6:6.

verses.text: So she left him and shut the door behind herself and her sons. They brought the jars to her, and she kept pouring.
verses.comment: The miraculous supply depended on her faith and obedience.

verses.text: When all the jars were full, she said to her son, 'Bring me another jar.' But he replied, 'There is not another.' Then the oil stopped flowing.
verses.comment: The supply ended when there were no more empty jars.

verses.text: She came and told the man of God. He said, 'Go, sell the oil and pay your debt. You and your sons can live on what remains.'
verses.comment: The miracle supplies both debt repayment and ongoing provision.

verses.text: One day Elisha went to Shunem. A prominent woman who lived there urged him to eat some food. So whenever he passed by, he would stop there to eat.
verses.comment: Introduction of the Shunammite woman.

verses.text: She said to her husband, 'Look, I know that this is a holy man of God who regularly passes by us.'
verses.comment: She recognizes Elisha’s status as a prophet.

verses.text: 'Please, let us make a small upper room and put a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp for him. So whenever he comes, he can stay there.'
verses.comment: Similar motif to hospitality extended to God's servants.

verses.text: One day he came there, and he turned in to the upper room and rested there.
He said to Gehazi his servant, 'Call this Shunammite woman.' When he had called her, she stood before him.
verses.comment: Gehazi acts as Elisha’s assistant.

verses.text: He said to him, 'Say to her, "Look, you have gone to all this trouble for us. What can be done for you? Should I speak on your behalf to the king or to the commander of the army?"' She answered, 'I live among my own people.'
verses.comment: She has no political need or ambition; she is content.

verses.text: He said, 'What then should be done for her?' Gehazi answered, 'Well, she has no son, and her husband is old.'
verses.comment: Parallels with Sarah and Abraham’s situation.

verses.text: He said, 'Call her.' When he had called her, she stood in the doorway.
He said, 'At this season next year, you will embrace a son.' She replied, 'No, my lord, man of God; do not lie to your servant.'
verses.comment: Similar to the promise to Sarah, disbelief conveys the improbability.

verses.text: But the woman conceived and bore a son at the appointed time the next year, as Elisha had spoken to her.
verses.comment: The miraculous fulfillment echoes Isaac’s birth.

verses.text: When the child had grown, he went out one day to his father among the reapers.
And he said to his father, 'My head, my head!' The father told a servant, 'Carry him to his mother.'
verses.comment: Child’s sudden pain, likely heat stroke or illness.

verses.text: When he had taken him and brought him to his mother, the boy sat on her lap until noon, and then he died.
verses.comment: Brief, poignant statement of the boy’s death.

verses.text: She went up and laid him on the bed of the man of God, shut the door behind him, and went out.
verses.comment: She lays him where the prophet had stayed, a place associated with God’s presence.

verses.text: She called to her husband and said, 'Please send me one of the servants and one of the donkeys, that I may quickly go to the man of God and return.'
He said, 'Why will you go to him today? It is neither new moon nor Sabbath.' She replied, 'It shall be well.'
verses.comment: New moon and Sabbath were set times for religious visitations.

verses.text: Then she saddled the donkey and said to her servant, 'Drive on; do not slow down for me unless I tell you.'
verses.comment: Immediacy and urgency show her faith and desperation.

verses.text: So she went and came to the man of God at Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to Gehazi his servant, 'Look, there is the Shunammite!'
verses.comment: Mount Carmel is a significant prophetic site—see 1 Kgs 18.

verses.text: 'Run at once to meet her and say to her, "Is it well with you? Is it well with your husband? Is it well with the child?"' She answered, 'It is well.'
verses.comment: Her answer conceals the truth or expresses faith.

verses.text: When she came to the man of God at the mountain, she grabbed his feet. Gehazi stepped forward to push her away, but the man of God said, 'Let her alone, for she is deeply troubled, and the LORD has hidden it from me and has not told me.'
verses.comment: Shows the prophet’s limited knowledge.

verses.text: Then she said, 'Did I ask my lord for a son? Did I not say, ‘Do not deceive me’?'
verses.comment: She refers back to her hesitation at the original promise.

verses.text: He said to Gehazi, 'Tie up your garment, take my staff in your hand, and go. If you meet anyone, do not greet him, and if anyone greets you, do not reply. Lay my staff on the face of the child.'
verses.comment: Instructions recall urgency and focus—no distractions.

verses.text: But the mother of the child said, 'As the LORD lives, and as you yourself live, I will not leave you.' So he arose and followed her.
verses.comment: This is a strong vow formula, emphasizing her determination.

verses.text: Gehazi went on ahead and laid the staff on the child’s face, but there was no sound or response. So he returned to meet him and told him, 'The child has not awakened.'
verses.comment: The staff alone did not restore the boy.

verses.text: When Elisha came into the house, he saw the child lying dead on his bed.
So he went in and shut the door behind the two of them and prayed to the LORD.
verses.comment: Privacy and prayer are central to the miracle.

verses.text: Then he went up and lay on the child, putting his mouth on his mouth, his eyes on his eyes, and his hands on his hands. As he stretched himself upon him, the child’s flesh became warm.
verses.comment: This action closely parallels Elijah’s miracle in 1 Kgs. 17.

verses.text: Then he got up and walked once back and forth in the house, and went up and stretched himself upon him again. The child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes.
verses.comment: The sneezing may symbolize the return of breath/life.

verses.text: He summoned Gehazi and said, 'Call this Shunammite.' So he called her. When she came to him, he said, 'Pick up your son.'
verses.comment: The mother is reunited with her now-living son.

verses.text: She came and fell at his feet, bowing to the ground. Then she picked up her son and went out.

Elisha returned to Gilgal, and there was a famine in the land. As the sons of the prophets were sitting before him, he said to his servant, 'Set on the large pot and cook stew for the sons of the prophets.'
verses.comment: Sets up the next miracle during a famine.

verses.text: One went out into the field to gather herbs and found a wild vine, and gathered from it a lapful of wild gourds. He came and cut them up into the pot of stew, not knowing what they were.
verses.comment: Wild gourds were possibly poisonous, a clear danger.

verses.text: They poured out some for the men to eat. But as they ate the stew, they cried out, 'O man of God, there is death in the pot!' They could not eat it.
verses.comment: The food is discovered to be poisonous or dangerous.

verses.text: But he said, 'Then bring some flour.' And he threw it into the pot and said, 'Pour some out for the people to eat.' And there was no harm in the pot.
verses.comment: The flour is not medicinal but a sign; it’s a miracle.

verses.text: A man came from Baal-shalishah, bringing the man of God bread of the firstfruits, twenty loaves of barley and fresh ears of grain in his sack. Elisha said, 'Give them to the people, that they may eat.'
verses.comment: Parallel to feeding miracles in the Gospels; ‘firstfruits’ link to offerings.

verses.text: But his servant said, 'How can I set this before a hundred men?' Elisha repeated, 'Give them to the people, that they may eat, for thus says the LORD, “They will eat and have some left over.”'
verses.comment: Theme of miraculous provision, having leftovers.

verses.text: So he set it before them. They ate, and had some left over, according to the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: Fulfillment of God’s word, prefigures later miracles (see John 6).
